sn3.10:1.1: Now at that time a large group of people had been put in shackles by King Pasenadi of Kosala—some in ropes, some in manacles, some in chains.
sn3.10:2.1: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
sn3.10:2.2: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
sn3.10:3.1: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha recited these verses:
sn3.10:4.1: “The wise say that shackle is not strong
sn3.10:4.2: that’s made of iron, wood, or knots.
sn3.10:4.4: concern for your partners and children:
sn3.10:5.1: this, say the wise, is a strong shackle
sn3.10:5.2: dragging the indulgent down, hard to escape.
sn3.10:5.3: Having cut this one too they go forth,
sn3.10:5.4: unconcerned, having given up sensual pleasures.”
